content.text: EXTERNAL INTERGRATED SUMMATIVE ASSESSMENTQuality Controller, NQF4 EXTERNAL INTERGRATED SUMMATIVE ASSESSMENTQuality Controller, NQF4
EXTERNAL INTEGRATED SUMMATIVE ASSESSMENT
QUALITY CONTROLLER
QUESTION PAPER 1D
GENERAL EISA RULES
1. Students are only allowed to use the supplied EISA booklets.
2. Students are only allowed to use a black pen for their answers.
3. Students to ensure that their name, surname and EISA registration number appears on the front of your EISA booklet.

4. This is a closed book examination; therefore, no other material or belongings are to be brought into the assessment centre.  Should you bring any other material or belongings into the assessment centre, you will be required to leave such at the front of the assessment centre examination room.  The assessment centre will not be held liable for any loss or damage to property brought into the assessment centre examination room.
5. All EISA booklets must be handed back to the invigilator intact.  No pages may be torn off from the EISA booklet.  The removal of EISA booklets from the examination room is prohibited.
6. Students may make use of a calculator in this EISA.

7. Unless this is an online examination where access to a computer will be made available to you; the use of any communication devices, including smart watches, cell phones, tablets, iPads, headphones and laptops are prohibited.
8. All cell phones are to be switched off for the duration of the EISA.
9. The invigilator will not assist you with the explanation of questions related to the EISA.
10. Students are prohibited from conversing in any manner with other students.
11. Students may not leave the examination venue within one hour of the start of the examination and in the last 10 minutes of the allotted examination period.
12. Students who are found to be disruptive and unruly in the assessment centre will be requested to leave the assessment centre by the invigilator.
I HEREBY CONFIRM THAT I HAVE READ THE ABOVE EISA RULES AND DECLARE THAT I
UNDERSTAND AND ACCEPT THE RULES.
SIGNATURE OF STUDENT
CANDIDATE INSTRUCTIONS
Candidate must complete all question s in the EISA
Candidates must ensure that they use only a black pen when completing this EISA.
Should you require additional space to complete your answer, please request additional paper from your invigilator.
Ensure that you indicate your name, surname and EISA registration number at the top of the additional paper.
Also ensure that the question number is clearly marked on your additional paper.
ur Sayzwani Abd Suki;Elmi Abu Bakar ,Shahrul Kamaruddin/ A Case Study on Improvement of Outgoing Quality Control Works for Manufacturing
Question 1.1
Complete a quality inspection checklist for input, inline and endline for product or service
(10 Marks)

rows: 1.1.1 Case StudyAllocate ten mark each for number 1 Use discretion to allocate marks for any other relevant point that may be given by the student.

content.text: Case Study:

Quality inspection is the measurements aimed at checking, measuring, or testing one or more product characteristics and relating the results to the requirements to confirm compliance. This task is usually performed by quality inspectors and does not fall within the responsibility of production workers.
Purpose of Quality Inspection
To distinguish good batches from bad batches
To distinguish good pieces from bad pieces.
To determine if the process is changing.
To determine if the process is approaching the specification limits.
To rate the quality of the product.
To rate the accuracy of inspectors.
To measure the precision of the measuring instrument.
To secure products – design information.
To measure process capability.

rows: When creating a check list for quality inspection, the above mentioned purposes of Quality inspection must be taken into consideration. Create a Quality Inspection checklist which will address the purposes of Quality Inspection listed above.

content.text: Identify whether testing and/or inspecting is applicable in a product manufactured or service environment.
(10 Marks)

rows: 1.1.2 Constructive Response Allocate ten marks Use discretion to allocate marks for any other relevant point that may be given by the student.

content.text: Quality parameter refer to the size characterizing the quality level of the final product/service, the quality of final products or services can be described using some of the following Quality Inspection process below:

rows: Looking at the process above at what stage will there be a need to perform either inspection or testing. Give industry related example to substantiate your answer.

content.text: 1.1.3 Complete a testing checklist for a product or service across all processes (input, inline and endline)
(10 Marks)

rows: 1.1.3 Case StudyAllocate ten mark each for number 1 Use discretion to allocate marks for any other relevant point that may be given by the student.

content.text: Service testing starts with the inputs, processing and outputs of services. It is important that inputs of services are tested for quality requirements before the service process starts. That is if the inputs are of good quality, it is likely that the quality services will be rendered.

rows: Generate a testing checklist that will ensure that there will be no gaps in the recruitment service process. The checklist should address all the steps in the process.

content.text: 1.1.4 Continuously inspect and test input, inline and endline to prevent non-conformance and make recommendations.
(15 Marks)

rows: 1.1.4 Case Study Allocate fifteen Marks for number 1 Use discretion to allocate marks for any other relevant point that may be given by the student.

content.text: The problem solving process can assist in making recommendations to prevent non-conformance during the input, inline and endline of a process

rows: Discuss the problem solving process which will assist in preventing non-conformance for the input, inline and endline

content.text: Apply knowledge of and adhere to good manufacturing principles (GMP) of product or good laboratory practices (GLP) of services
(10 Marks)

rows: 1.1.5 Constructive Response Allocate 10 marks for number 1

content.text: 1.16 Apply different testing methods for different characteristics to test for product/service quality applicable in their environment
(10 Marks)

rows: 1.1.6 Case Study Allocate ten marks for no1 Use discretion to allocate marks for any other relevant point that may be given by the student.

content.text: Case Study:

Testing methodologies are applied in different types of industries.  The types of tests conducted depend on the products/services being produced, these tests are important for a company to grow and to be competitive.

rows: Discuss the five test methodology below in details and give industry example.Integration testingUnit testingSystem testingPerformance testingLoad testing

content.text: Apply knowledge of testing procedures of a product or service.
(10 Marks)

rows: 1.1.7 Constructive Response Allocate ten marks for no1Use discretion to allocate marks for any other relevant point that may be given by the student.

content.text: Random testing is often a difficult practice to approach for businesses in all industries. Both established and growing businesses need the same questions answered in regard to how they should implement a random test program.

rows: Discuss Random testing and the 9 guidelines for an effective random testing program:

content.text: Test if product/service conforms to the required standard
(5 Marks)

rows: 1.1.8 Multiple Choice Questions Allocate 1 mark each for number 1 to 5
The quality of the final product /service is determined by the characteristics ofResource FunctioningResource TestingResource AllocationResource Analysing
A quality problem may occur due to Lack of resource, Skilled employeesPoor managementAll of the above
When carrying   out the remedial measures, The Shewhart PDCA cycle Means       A.   Plan, Check, Do, Apply       B.Plan, Check, Do, Adopt       C.Plan, Check, Do, Analyse       D.None of the above
When analysing a problem it may be necessary to look beyond the obvious by,Seek other perspectivesBe flexible in your analysisConsider various strands of impacts All of the above
This technique is used to give a rough assessment for the probability of a source of a problem            A.  Flow Diagram       B.Pareto Charts        C.Histogram       D.Cause and effect diagram

content.text: Question 2.1
2.1.1 Identify tools (what) and method (how) to use in processing information during manufacturing and service rendering
(5 Marks)

rows: 2.1.1 Multiple Choice Question Allocate one mark each for number 1 to 5

Used by quality assurance personnel to validate the quality of purchased raw materials based on set acceptance criteria Technical datasheetCertificate of ConformanceInspection checklistTesting checklist

Documented information needs to be maintained by the organization to establishThe scope of the quality management system.The information which will not support the operation of processes.Measure to hide the quality policy and procedures.None of the above
3 steps constituting the data processing cycle are:Input, Output, ProcessProcess, Input, OutputInput, Process, OutputAll of the above

Collation plays the following roles:Can be used as a tool to control theft.Customer complaints are listed in files and can be attended to promptly.The prices for different products are listed accordingly.All of the above.

Customer complaints documents are inputs used to:attend to complaints from customers Attend customer complaint from employeesAttend customer complaints from managersAttends customer complaints from suppliers

content.text: 2.1.4 Make recommendation for process improvements based on the analysis  (15 Marks)
